Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1437545

This project will explore the behavior of liquid drops that have small particles adsorbed on their interfaces. When the drops are placed in an electric field, the particles on the interface can assemble into a variety of interesting structures, including particle belts that rotate and undulate around the drop. These structures can become unstable in some conditions, leading to bucking or wrinkling. The investigators will experimentally map out the structures that form as a function of fluid, particle, and electric field properties. Then, they will use the experimental results to develop a model to predict the observed instabilities. When the particles completely cover the interface of the drop, the interface resembles an elastic solid. The way the drop shape deforms in flow will be used to deduce the mechanical characteristics of the interface. The information from this project will be useful to scientists and engineers to design and process novel colloidal products such as drops with interfaces that can respond to their local environment.

Electrohydrodynamic flow in leaky-dielectric liquid drops can be used to structure and manipulate colloidal particles at the drop surface. This project will establish the mechanisms of particle assembly on a drop placed in an electric field to relate particle architectures and drop behavior to control parameters such as field strength, particle and fluid properties. Experimental studies will be carried out for drops with low particle coverage to construct a phase diagram of particle structures and the influence of particle structure on drop deformation in flow will be measured. For high surface coverage drops, drop deformation will be used to determine elastic properties of the interface. A leaky dielectric model and small deformation theory will be used to relate drop deformation and elastic properties of the interface and to predict the electric field threshold for rotation of the drops as a function of surface conductivity. The research outcomes will lead to the engineering of novel colloidal-coated drops with versatile and controllable surface coverage.

Institution.Name: Brown University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BROWN UNIVERSITY IN PROVIDENCE IN THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electric fields animate flows around drops. If small particles are trapped at the interface, these particles organize into a variety of intriguing structures. This research showed the particle assemblies arise from the interplay of particle collective dynamics and flow instabilities.  The research also discovered novel phenomenon: an electric field can squash  a millimeter-sized oil drop, causing it to shed thin rings from its equator that then break up into tiny droplets.

The emergent behavior and intricate patterns formed by the surface- trapped particles in electric fields could provide novel ways to create structurally complex materials with tailored optical, mechanical, magnetic, or electric properties. The streaming. The equatorial streaming allows the production of large number of microdroplets in a relatively short time, “electroemulsification,” with potential applications in industrial processes.

One PhD student, two post-doctoral researchers, and two undergraduate students were trained in electrohydrodynamics. The research resulted in 8 publications in peer-reviewed journals.   Outreach was performed to pre-K students and the general audience about electricity and fluids; in particular, the electrohydrodynamic streaming phenomenon generated a lot of media interest, because of the visually striking Saturn-like appearance of the drop (see the accompanying Figure and https://physics.aps.org/synopsis-for/10.1103/PhysRevLett.119.034501)  

 

Figure: Microparticles constrained to a drop interface can organize in variety of structures depending on electric field strength Ca, particle polarizability, and coverage.  Particles can form an undulating belt around the equator (A,B) or pole-to-pole chains aligned with the applied field (C).  (D) Streaming from the drop equator creates “Saturn rings”.  Image of the drop as a whole and zoom-in at the equator. Drop and suspending fluids are silicon and castor oils, respectively.


Last Modified: 03/29/2018
Modified by: Petia Vlahovska

    Petia Vlahovska, Malika Ouriemi, Quentin Brosseau

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Electric fields animate flows around drops. If small particles are trapped at the interface, these particles organize into a variety of intriguing structures. This research showed the particle assemblies arise from the interplay of particle collective dynamics and flow instabilities. The research also discovered novel phenomenon: an electric field can squash a millimeter-sized oil drop, causing it to shed thin rings from its equator that then break up into tiny droplets. The emergent behavior and intricate patterns formed by the surface- trapped particles in electric fields could provide novel ways to create structurally complex materials with tailored optical, mechanical, magnetic, or electric properties. The streaming. The equatorial streaming allows the production of large number of microdroplets in a relatively short time, "electroemulsification," with potential applications in industrial processes. One PhD student, two post-doctoral researchers, and two undergraduate students were trained in electrohydrodynamics. The research resulted in 8 publications in peer-reviewed journals. Outreach was performed to pre-K students and the general audience about electricity and fluids; in particular, the electrohydrodynamic streaming phenomenon generated a lot of media interest, because of the visually striking Saturn-like appearance of the drop (see the accompanying Figure and https://physics.aps.org/synopsis-for/10.1103/PhysRevLett.119.034501) Figure: Microparticles constrained to a drop interface can organize in variety of structures depending on electric field strength Ca, particle polarizability, and coverage.
